item.title: Issue: Bad setting leading to full load of data regardless of Virtual Mode - @tumblingstuff
item.description:
There's a vital piece of optimization that is done wrong in this example - the DataGridView.AutoSizeColumnMode is set to .AllCells. That requires loading the entire set of rows, not just the displayed window, to calculate cell widths. That means the CellValueNeeded event is called for every cell in every row of the data upon initialization; hardly the desired behavior for a Virtual Mode table.

The AutoSizeColumnMode should be set to .DisplayedCells or .None, so display only requires fetching a few lines. The speed difference in my code for setting the .RowCount value (~50K rows, 10 columns, 8 lines displayed) was 45 seconds for AllCells versus ~4 milliseconds for DisplayedCells. This should be a key recommendation for Virtual Mode. [Enter feedback here]

Document Details

⚠ Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.

  • ID: aec74745-9e0c-9e4a-d749-d877ea4c3d38

item.title: Issue: Update Debugging WinForms Controls tutorial page to indicate this doesn't work for .NET controls. - @merriemcgaw
item.description:
Users are attempting to use this page to create and debug WinForms .NET controls. This no longer works given that our designer now runs out of process. @KlausLoeffelmann is creating a doc to show how to do this. We're working on blogs and other docs to cover the WinForms .NET controls creation process currently and how to debug them. We will be creating an WinForms Designer SDK Extensibility samples repo shortly that will include samples and how to docs for everything.

item.title: Issue: [doc bug]: D3DCode.DLL is not included in the legacy direct X install - @maross3
item.description:
Article URL

https://github.com/dotnet/docs-desktop/blob/main/dotnet-desktop-guide/framework/wpf/advanced/walkthrough-hosting-direct3d9-content-in-wpf.md

Technology

WPF (Windows Presentation Foundation)

Version

  • [X] .NET 5 or later (also .NET Core)
  • [X] .NET Framework 4

Description

D3DCode.DLL is not included in the legacy direct X SDK install, nor windows SDK 10 install. all of the documentation in regards to using direct X and WPF seems to be outdated. The documentation should be removed/archived if no longer supported, or updated if there is another work around for the interops of DX and WPF.

item.title: Issue: [Tracking] Consider renaming "up-for-grabs" label to "help wanted" & "good-first-issue" to "good first issue" - @mairaw

item.title: Issue: Add warning that DragEnter does not work unless Canvas Background is set - @techfan101
item.description:
For the most part, this page was very helpful and clearly written. However, there is one "gotcha" that can cause a huge headache for your readers.

It occurs with controls like the Canvas control. In addition to setting the AllowDrop property, it is also necessary to set the Background property. Otherwise, the Canvas is not recognized as a valid drop target, the "not allowed" cursor is displayed, and the DragEnter and Drop events never fire.

Adding a simple warning about the Background property could save developers a lot of time.

I recently spent an afternoon re-discovering this entirely non-obvious requirement. It would be great if you could help other developers avoid this time waste :) Thank you.

Document Details

⚠ Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.

  • ID: 0d8003ab-20fc-501b-dc2a-a1810449483d
  • Version Independent ID: ca183356-078d-1538-1aa4-d3d7d604231b
  • Content: Drag and Drop Overview - WPF .NET Framework
  • Content Source: dotnet-desktop-guide/framework/wpf/advanced/drag-and-drop-overview.md
  • Product: dotnet-framework
  • Technology: dotnet-wpf

  • Microsoft Alias: adegeo

item.title: Issue: High DPI support app.config sample typo - @afrowuk
item.description:
The app.config sample on this page shows a root node of <compatibility xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:compatibility.v1">, but should have a <configuration> root node. I suspect this is a copy and paste typo from the app.manifest sample above it.

Edit: The following page has a correct app.config sample usage: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/configure-apps/file-schema/winforms/

item.title: Issue: Documentation needed for hosting WPF control in WinForms targeting .NET Core - @MisinformedDNA
item.description:
The documentation for hosting a WPF control in WinForms is only given for .NET Framework. There needs to be parallel documentation for .NET Core.

For instance, the .NET Framework documentation says to

Add references to the following assemblies.

  • PresentationCore
  • PresentationFramework
  • System.Xaml
  • WindowsBase
  • WindowsFormsIntegration

But what is the equivalent in .NET Core?

I also took a look at the samples, but I don't see one where the WinForms app is targeting .NET Core.

Document Details

item.title: Issue: page tells you to dispose of *any* objects that consume memory - @ArjanWiegelBrunelco
item.description:
"You should always call Dispose on any objects that consume system resources, such as Pen and Graphics objects." Unaware users could take this advice literally. Please update the text to something in the line of: "You should always call Dispose on any objects that you created and consume system resources, such as Pen and Graphics objects. Do not dispose of objects that you borrow from parent objects"

Document Details

item.title: Issue: Visual Studio Designer: Timed out while connecting to named pipe. - @tommai78101
item.description:
The article linked to this issue does not mention anything about a "named pipe".

I received an error message mentioning this:

Timed out while connecting to named pipe. 

Instances of this error (1)  
 
1.   Hide Call Stack 
 
at Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.Host.ServerProcess.d__35.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
at Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.Host.ServerProcess.d__28.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
at Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.Host.ServerHostFactory.d__7.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
at Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.DesignToolsClientLoader.d__28.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
at Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.DesignToolsClientLoader.<>c__DisplayClass24_1.<<-ctor>b__1>d.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
at Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.DesignToolsClientLoader.d__26.MoveNext()

And here's the attachment to reproduce the error:

Application.zip

This ZIP file contains the full Visual Studio 2022 solution that will produce the error.

What do I do to fix this issue? I would like to request for someone to add this error to this page, as well as the steps to resolve this problem.

item.title: Issue: [doc bug]: Be more specific about where to place the `System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationConfigurationSection` tag in the `app.config` file - @astrohart
item.description:
Article URL

https://github.com/dotnet/docs-desktop/blob/main/dotnet-desktop-guide/framework/winforms/high-dpi-support-in-windows-forms.md

Technology

Windows Forms

Version

  • [ ] .NET 5 or later (also .NET Core)
  • [x] .NET Framework 4

Description

In the document that is at the URL referenced above, there is a section of the documentation that advises the reader to place the following code in the app.config file of the user's project:

<System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationConfigurationSection>
  <add key="DpiAwareness" value="PerMonitorV2" />
</System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationConfigurationSection>

However, I suggest that the document be updated in order to show more specificity about where in the XML hierarchy of the app.config file, the new code is to be inserted.

For example, should I place it between the <configuration> and </configuration> tags, or at the root level? I had to guess, since this documentation doesn't say. I ended up finding out it has to be placed at the following level:

<configuration>
<!-- ... -->
    <System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationConfigurationSection>
      <add key="DpiAwareness" value="PerMonitorV2" />
    </System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationConfigurationSection>
<!-- ... -->
</configuration>

The article, in my opinion, could use some fine-tuning to add the code bit I just wrote, above, so as to give more context as to where the System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationConfigurationSection element is to be placed in the overall XML schema of the file as a whole. So that I, and other readers, do not have to guess.

item.title: Issue: e.Data.GetDataPresent not working as expected - @anewton
item.description:
In the instructions for section To process the dropped data, the method e.Data.GetDataPresent was not working for a WPF app that targets net6.0-windows. Replacing the code if (e.Data.GetDataPresent(DataFormats.StringFormat)) with if (e.Data.GetData(DataFormats.StringFormat) != null) works.

Document Details
